trial_identification.studytitle: Non melancholic depression: a naturalistic treatment outcome study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of in-house psychological treatment at the Black Dog Institute Depression Clinic on severity of symptoms in participants with non-melancholic depression who have tried two or more antidepressants

interventions.interventions: All treatment in this trial forms part of routine clinical management. Patients in the "treatment" group receive ten 50 minute sessions with a Black Dog Institute Clinical Psychologist over a 12 week period. The first 8 sessions are weekly, and the last two sessions are fortnightly.There is no uniform psychological treatment used for all patients - rather, treatment type is tailored to the patients particular concerns (as it would be in the "real" world).
interventions.comparator: An "external" group - comprised of those patients who (for whatever reason) are not able to attend the Black Dog Institute for twelve weeks of treatment - are also assessed over the twelve week period. Patients in this group will be compared with those in the treatment group but will fall into roughly twp categories: those who receive (external) psychological intervention, and those who do not.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Depression severity as measured by the Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology - Self-Report (QIDS)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, weekly from week 1 - week 10, follow-up (at 12 weeks)
Baseline, weekly from week 1 - week 10, follow-up (at 12 weeks)

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, weekly from week 1 - week 10, follow-up (at 12 weeks)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Work Productivity and Activity Impairment Scale (WPAI)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, weekly from week 1 - week 10, follow-up (at 12 weeks)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis by BDI Psychiatrist of non-melancholic depression Over 18 years old Tried two or more antidepressants - at least one must have been a trial of more than 4 weeks with cessation not entirely due to side effects Not have received psychological therapy within the last 3 months
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Under 18 years old Significant comorbidities present Current drug and alcohol problems

trial_design.concealment: If a patient meets the eligibility criteria for the study, the group (treatment versus external) that they enter is entirely dependent on whether they can attend ten weekly sessions at the BDI (in Randwick). If this is not possible - they are automatically assigned to the external group. Allocation to groups is not concealed to participants.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The current research aims to determine whether changing the treatment paradigm from a drug to a non-drug (i.e psychological) approach will result in improved outcomes for those with a unipolar non-melancholic depression. By altering the primary treatment approach, we hypothesise that more positive outcomes are likely to occur.
